fields.Title of Contribution: HIGH PREVALENCE OF LEUCOCYTOZOON PARASITES IN NESTLING NORTHERN GOSHAWKS (ACCIPITER GENTILIS) IN THE NORTHERN GREAT BASIN USA.
fields.Description/Abstract:
The Northern Goshawk (Accipiter gentilis) is currently listed as a sensitive species by the
U.S.D.A. Forest Service. Previous research in our study area, the South Hills of the Minidoka
Ranger District of the Sawtooth National Forest, Idaho, showed possible signs of parasite
infections among the banded adults and nestlings, which could influence their breeding success.
Therefore, we sought to quantify the prevalence and intensity of Leucocytozoon parasites among
nestling goshawks in the unique sky island habitat in south-central Idaho during the 2012
breeding season. We sampled 27 nestlings from 12 nests for Leucocytozoon parasites by
examining blood smears. All of these nestlings were infected with Leucocytozoon parasites. The
infection intensity of ranged from 8.20 - 100.45 Leucocytozoon parasites per 10,000 erythrocytes
(mean ± SE = 43.52 ± 5.37). Using elevation, distance-to-water, nestling age, sex and nesting
substrate as predictor variables for infection intensity by Leucocytozoon parasites, we employed
an information theoretic approach to select a top model to determine the presence of an effect.
Our top model included nesting substrate and elevation as the sole predictors of infection
intensity. Specifically, higher Leucocytozoon parasite intensity was associated with higher
elevation and aspen nesting substrate. The within-nest correlation was 94%. Our results show
that there is a high prevalence of Leucocytozoon parasites in this population of goshawks and
that nesting substrate and elevation may influence infection intensity. Further research will help
identify management implications for this species of concern, as well as other avian species in
this unusual high altitude shrub-steppe ecosystem.
